188883.title: Remain calm and be prepared to wait.  Showing impatience can increase pressure to pay.  Use any or all of these statements to help you explain why you won't pay.

nodes.text: Remain courteous, respectful and if possible friendly
Make it clear that your company does not allow you to make payments of this kind / that your head office doesn’t allow me to pay any fee that isn’t official
Ask for name and official title of person asking and any identity number
State that you would need an official receipt if you were to pay the fee
Ask to speak to the supervisor/manager of the person making the demand to discuss why you cant pay
Mention that you will contact the embassy / consulate to discuss / report the issue
Explain that you must call your company first to report the issue and to get permission to pay the fee
Take notes or make mental note of the conversations and the time and place for a later report
Report it

Being asked to pay a small sum of money to an official as a fine can sometimes be a facilitation payment in disguise. However, as this is a published fine and you will get a receipt it is unlikely to be a facilitation payment in this instance.  Be cautious though and if you are in any doubt do not pay.

We make no distinction between facilitation payments and bribes, no matter how small the amount. Facilitation payments are illegal in most countries in which we operate and UK law forbids them anywhere in the world.
Obtain a receipt detailing the reason for and the amount of the charge.
Record the transaction appropriately.
If you are in any doubt do not pay.
Gifts should only be accepted as a one off and not one of many from the same person / company.  The exception would be company branded promotional items.
If you have been offered or have received non promotional gifts such as this or similar from this person or company before, talk to your manager before accepting.

The danger of accepting multiple gifts from business contacts is that, unfairly or not, colleagues and others including other business partners, may question your impartiality and professional integrity.  The more frequently you accept gifts the more chance this may happen.

Although you may believe that this gift is offered with no ulterior motive, multiple gifts even of low value, could be misinterpreted by others who could perceive acceptance as making you or your decisions biased, conflicted or obligated.  It maybe safer to decline on this occasion than to take the risk.

As the gift is not a promotional item do not be embarrassed to decline it and be clear that you are by doing so in writing.  Simply explain that you are not in a position to accept them using the rules and the reasons given here as explanation.
If you feel it is appropriate to accept the gift, report it to your line manager.
Always acknowledge the acceptance of a gift in writing to the sender.

Hospitality is a legitimate part of business life and creates the chance to talk business in a social, less pressurised atmosphere. However, particular care must be taken when we are negotiating or considering contracts.  Although this may be a legitimate offer the timing is inappropriate. Hospitality should not be accepted during a tender, bid or contract negotiation process, irrespective of the value.

There is a risk that accepting the offer of hospitality at this time may create a sense of obligation, impair independence or judgement or improperly influence decisions during the negotiation process or the outcome.  Gifts can influence decisions and behaviour both consciously and subconsciously.

Whilst you may believe that the hospitality is offered with no ulterior motive it could be misinterpreted by others who could perceive the acceptance of the offer as making you or your decisions biased, conflicted or obligated.  It is safer to decline than take the risk.

Do not be embarrassed to decline the offer of hospitality and be clear that you are by doing so in writing.  Simply explain that you are not in a position to accept it using the rules and the reasons given here as explanation.
Report this offer of hospitality to your line manager, the bid contract or the Legal department and be clear that you have declined it.
If you have a gift and hospitality register make sure you record the hospitality and the fact you declined it on this too.

Never seek hospitality or even be mistaken for asking for it especially during a bid, tender or contract negotiation process.  This would seriously damage your personal reputation as well as the reputation of the company.  Regardless of the reason for doing so seeking hospitality of any sort could be interpreted as a commitment by you to influence the process.
Talk to your manager before proceeding. Hospitality should only be accepted on an infrequent basis from the same person / company.
